Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Reconstruction of Paleo-Storm History Using Geochemical Proxies in Coastal Lake Sediments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will use historical information spanning thousands of years from coastal lake sediments to advance scientific understanding of hurricanes and their relationship to climate change. This knowledge could help coastal planners better manage the risk that hurricanes pose to coastal communities. The results will be shared on public websites of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. This project will provide research training for both undergraduate and graduate students at Florida State University and the University of Central Florida. It will also provide research experience to K-12 students and teachers from education programs at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory in Tallahassee, FL.

Recent studies suggest that organic geochemical proxies preserved in coastal lake sediments are a sensitive indicator for storm events and can be used to reconstruct paleo-storm history. This project aims to examine the isotopic systematics in coastal lakes in northern and eastern Florida, and to develop high-resolution multi-proxy records of storms and environmental changes during the late Holocene for these regions via analyses of geochemical proxies. The results will be used to test hypotheses concerning the possible linkage between sea surface temperature and hurricane activity. This effort could help constrain predictive models that describe how global warming will affect regional climate conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  This project is aimed to calibrate modern coastal lake systems with respect to the natural variability of geochemical proxies and to apply this calibration to sediment cores from coastal lakes along portions of the Florida coasts to develop high-resolution multi-proxy records of past hurricane activities during the last millennia for the study areas. The outcomes of the project are summarized below.

Our systematic analyses of radiocarbon data from coastal lakes in Florida show that radiocarbon dates on bulk sediment organic matter (a commonly used radiocarbon dating material in paleo-hurricane and paleo-environmental studies) are always older than dates on concurrent plants and shells.  This indicates that radiocarbon ages obtained from bulk sediment organic matter from coastal lakes are generally unreliable. Our data suggest that fresh/brackish water shells may serve as a useful substrate for obtaining reliable radiocarbon dates. But radiocarbon ages of shell fragments associated with sand deposits in coastal lakes are likely a few hundred years too old due to their possible marine origin and the influence of marine radiocarbon reservoir effect. Radiocarbon age reversals in sediment cores are most likely caused by rapid increases in erosion and sedimentation resulting from large storm events.  Furthermore, our data show that sedimentation rate can vary considerably within a lake.  This implies that an age-depth model established for one sediment core cannot be directly applied to other cores from the same lake. These findings have important implications for developing reliable radiocarbon-based chronologies in studies of past hurricanes and paleoenvironmental changes utilizing physical, biological, and chemical proxies preserved in coastal lake sediments.

Our 3-year time-series data from two coastal lakes in Florida demonstrate the feasibility of detecting past storms that caused either seawater flooding or freshwater flooding by examining the variation patterns of multiple organic geochemical proxies (including carbon and nitrogen elemental and isotopic ratios) in coastal lake sediments. Our data show that seawater flooding can result in two possible variation patterns of organic geochemical proxies in these coastal lakes. Freshwater flooding, on the other hand, can lead to four possible variation patterns of these proxies in the lakes. These multi-proxy variation patterns, if preserved in lake sediments, could be used as fingerprints to identify past storm events that impacted the lakes. Applying this understanding to a coastal lake sediment core, we reconstructed a centuries-long record of storms based on the variation patterns of multiple geochemical proxies. Almost all the flooding events identified in sediment record can be matched (within the dating uncertainty) to the historic hurricanes that are known to have passed within 150 km of the study site. This further confirms that the organic geochemical proxies preserved in coastal lake sediments are a reliable recorder of hurricane activity and the method can be applied to these and other lake sites with similar conditions (i.e., near the ocean and in a vegetated watershed) to reconstruct paleo-storm history. 

We have produced multiple organic geochemical proxy data from several other sediment cores from selected coastal lakes in Florida. The data are used to reconstruct millennia-long proxy records of storm activities for the study lake areas. Our reconstructions show that hurricane activity recorded as flooding events has varied significantly on multi-decadal, centennial, and longer time scales.  Comparison of these results with other paleo-hurricane and paleo-climate records based on other proxies will contribute to understanding the long-term pattern in hurricane activity and its relation to climate change.

Broader Impacts: This project supported the dissertation research and training of one graduate student and provided additional research experience to another graduate student at Florida State University.  The project also provided valuable hands-on research experience to three undergraduate students, one visiting student, and two K-12 teachers. The results will contribute to understanding the long-term patterns of hurricane activity along  the Florida coasts - regions highly susceptible to hurricane landfall.
